More GPs are practicing in rural areas.
Demand for GPs in rural areas still exceeds supply.
The analysis focuses on GP numbers in Queensland.
The increase is a positive step, but more are needed.

The abuse is related to access pathways for cannabis.

clusters.title: What is polygenic embryo screening in IVF and does it work?
clusters.neutral_headline: What is polygenic embryo screening in IVF and does it work?: Scientists have developed algorithms that give predictive scores for a host of physical and mental traitsUK IVF couples use legal loophole to rank embryos based on potential IQ, height and healthThe Guardian has learned that couples undergoing IVF in the UK are exploiting an apparent legal loophole to rank their embryos based on genetic predictions of IQ. But what is polygenic screening and does it work? Continue reading

items.title: What is polygenic embryo screening in IVF and does it work?
items.standfirst: Scientists have developed algorithms that give predictive scores for a host of physical and mental traitsUK IVF couples use legal loophole to rank embryos based on potential IQ, height and healthThe Guardian has learned that couples undergoing IVF in the UK are exploiting an apparent legal loophole to rank their embryos based on genetic predictions of IQ. But what is polygenic screening and does it work? Continue reading...
items.content: Scientists have developed algorithms that give predictive scores for a host of physical and mental traitsUK IVF couples use legal loophole to rank embryos based on potential IQ, height and healthThe Guardian has learned that couples undergoing IVF in the UK are exploiting an apparent legal loophole to rank their embryos based on genetic predictions of IQ. But what is polygenic screening and does it work? Continue reading...

items.title: UK IVF couples use legal loophole to rank embryos based on potential IQ, height and health
items.standfirst: British fertility clinics raise scientific and ethical objections over patients sending embryos’ genetic data abroad for analysisWhat is polygenic embryo screening in IVF and does it work?Couples undergoing IVF in the UK are exploiting an apparent legal loophole to rank their embryos based on genetic predictions of IQ, height and health, the Guardian has learned.The controversial screening technique, which scores embryos based on their DNA, is not permitted at UK fertility clinics and critics have raised scientific and ethical objections, saying the method is unproven. But under data protection laws, patients can – and in some cases have – demanded their embryos’ raw genetic data and sent it abroad for analysis in an effort to have smarter, healthier children. Continue reading...
items.content: British fertility clinics raise scientific and ethical objections over patients sending embryos’ genetic data abroad for analysisWhat is polygenic embryo screening in IVF and does it work?Couples undergoing IVF in the UK are exploiting an apparent legal loophole to rank their embryos based on genetic predictions of IQ, height and health, the Guardian has learned.The controversial screening technique, which scores embryos based on their DNA, is not permitted at UK fertility clinics and critics have raised scientific and ethical objections, saying the method is unproven. But under data protection laws, patients can – and in some cases have – demanded their embryos’ raw genetic data and sent it abroad for analysis in an effort to have smarter, healthier children. Continue reading...

ai_summary: UK couples use a loophole to rank embryos via genetic data.
The ranking is based on potential IQ, height, and health.
The screening method is not permitted in UK clinics.
Couples send data abroad for embryo analysis.
Critics raise scientific and ethical objections to the method.

clusters.title: Who’s allowed to get the hepatitis B vaccine in the US now?
clusters.neutral_headline: Who’s allowed to get the hepatitis B vaccine in the US now?: Advisers for the CDC voted to limit the vaccines – here’s what happened and why the vote is so significantVaccine advisers for the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) voted on Friday morning to limit hepatitis B vaccines to most babies in a major move signaling the Trump administration’s regressive approach to vaccines that have been given safely and effectively for decades.What is the situation now and what does this mean? Continue reading

items.title: Key US panel to vote on changing infant hepatitis B vaccine recommendation
items.standfirst: ACIP vote follows two postponements and contentious meeting and comes as RFK Jr pushes for vaccine delayAfter a delay and an unusually contentious meeting, a federal vaccine advisory panel was expected to vote on Friday whether to change the longstanding recommendation that all newborns be immunized against hepatitis B.The first day of the meeting of the advisory committee on immunization practices (ACIP) on Thursday was marked by heated debate over restricting access to the hepatitis B vaccine for infants and a decision to defer the vote by a day to give members more time to review the wording. The panel, which advises the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) on how to use vaccines, had twice before postponed the vote. Continue reading...
items.content: ACIP vote follows two postponements and contentious meeting and comes as RFK Jr pushes for vaccine delayAfter a delay and an unusually contentious meeting, a federal vaccine advisory panel was expected to vote on Friday whether to change the longstanding recommendation that all newborns be immunized against hepatitis B.The first day of the meeting of the advisory committee on immunization practices (ACIP) on Thursday was marked by heated debate over restricting access to the hepatitis B vaccine for infants and a decision to defer the vote by a day to give members more time to review the wording. The panel, which advises the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) on how to use vaccines, had twice before postponed the vote. Continue reading...

items.title: CDC advisers delay vote on restricting infant hepatitis B vaccinations in tense meeting
items.standfirst: From 1990 to 2019, reported cases of acute hepatitis B among kids declined by 99% due to infant immunizationAfter a contentious meeting, vaccine advisers for the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) voted on Thursday to delay a vote on restricting hepatitis B vaccination for infants until Friday.The meeting of the advisory committee on immunization practices (ACIP) turned confrontational at times before one member introduced a motion to delay the vote, which passed by six to three, to give advisers time to examine the wording before taking a vote. Continue reading...
items.content: From 1990 to 2019, reported cases of acute hepatitis B among kids declined by 99% due to infant immunizationAfter a contentious meeting, vaccine advisers for the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) voted on Thursday to delay a vote on restricting hepatitis B vaccination for infants until Friday.The meeting of the advisory committee on immunization practices (ACIP) turned confrontational at times before one member introduced a motion to delay the vote, which passed by six to three, to give advisers time to examine the wording before taking a vote. Continue reading...

ai_summary: CDC advisers voted to limit hepatitis B vaccines.
The vote may restrict infant hepatitis B vaccinations.
The meeting was marked by heated debate.
The vote was delayed due to the contentious meeting.
The decision could impact infant immunization practices.

clusters.title: AI deepfakes of real doctors spreading health misinformation on social media
clusters.neutral_headline: AI deepfakes of real doctors spreading health misinformation on social media: Hundreds of videos on TikTok and elsewhere impersonate experts to sell supplements with unproven effects TikTok and other social media platforms are hosting AI-generated deepfake videos of doctors whose words have been manipulated to help sell supplements and spread health misinformation.The factchecking organisation Full Fact has uncovered hundreds of such videos featuring impersonated versions of doctors and influencers directing viewers to Wellness Nest, a US-based supplements firm. Continue reading

clusters.title: Turner’s mother’s frustration and a memorable brush with Bacon | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Turner’s mother’s frustration and a memorable brush with Bacon | Letters: Dr Selby Whittingham considers the ill-treatment of Turner’s mother, while Paul Collins recalls taking one artist to see another’s work. Plus letters from Martin Argles and John CaperonMy answer to the pertinent question put by Helen James in her letter (Was JMW Turner’s mother really ‘mentally ill’?, 27 November) is that whatever illness Mary may have had would have been greatly increased by the frustration that she must have felt with her circumstances in the mean lodging in Covent Garden, which her husband lacked the ambition to better. These contrasted with the comfortable Islington home in which she grew up and with the even more prosperous circumstances of her relations. I have discussed those in the Genealogists’ Magazine, the British Art Journal and now in my publication for Turner 250: Happy Birthdays! JMW Turner and Prince George on Richmond Hill. Since I wrote the last, a plaque was erected on the site of the house of the uncle of Turner in Brentford, where he was sent to escape the bedlam at home and where, like Beethoven at a similar age at Bonn, he acquired lifelong cultured friends.Dr Selby WhittinghamSecretary, the Independent Turner Society • Regarding artistic rivalries, including that between JMW Turner and John Constable (28 November), in 1969 I met Francis Bacon at a health hydro in Surrey. He claimed to have been sent by his agent to dry out. His unaffected friendliness overcame my awe at encountering the great painter. In my first Mini, I drove him to see the Turners at Petworth House, where there happened to be a William Blake exhibition as well. He was dismissive of Blake as an artist, preferring the poetry. But the surprise was his little concern for the Petworth Turners, which he hadn’t seen before. I prefer Constable, he said. The following day he felt obliged to go to Guildford (by himself) for a glass of burgundy.Paul CollinsHorton cum Studley, O

The following day he felt obliged to go to Guildford (by himself) for a glass of burgundy.Paul CollinsHorton cum Studley, Oxfordshire Continue reading...
items.content: Dr Selby Whittingham considers the ill-treatment of Turner’s mother, while Paul Collins recalls taking one artist to see another’s work. Plus letters from Martin Argles and John CaperonMy answer to the pertinent question put by Helen James in her letter (Was JMW Turner’s mother really ‘mentally ill’?, 27 November) is that whatever illness Mary may have had would have been greatly increased by the frustration that she must have felt with her circumstances in the mean lodging in Covent Garden, which her husband lacked the ambition to better. These contrasted with the comfortable Islington home in which she grew up and with the even more prosperous circumstances of her relations. I have discussed those in the Genealogists’ Magazine, the British Art Journal and now in my publication for Turner 250: Happy Birthdays! JMW Turner and Prince George on Richmond Hill. Since I wrote the last, a plaque was erected on the site of the house of the uncle of Turner in Brentford, where he was sent to escape the bedlam at home and where, like Beethoven at a similar age at Bonn, he acquired lifelong cultured friends.Dr Selby WhittinghamSecretary, the Independent Turner Society • Regarding artistic rivalries, including that between JMW Turner and John Constable (28 November), in 1969 I met Francis Bacon at a health hydro in Surrey. He claimed to have been sent by his agent to dry out. His unaffected friendliness overcame my awe at encountering the great painter. In my first Mini, I drove him to see the Turners at Petworth House, where there happened to be a William Blake exhibition as well. He was dismissive of Blake as an artist, preferring the poetry. But the surprise was his little concern for the Petworth Turners, which he hadn’t seen before. I prefer Constable, he said. The following day he felt obliged to go to Guildford (by himself) for a glass of burgundy.Paul CollinsHorton cum Studley, Oxfordshire Continue reading...

ai_summary: A letter discusses Turner's mother's mental health.
The letter explores the impact of her circumstances.
Another letter recalls meeting Francis Bacon.
Bacon was taken to see Turner's work.
Bacon preferred Constable to Turner's work.

clusters.title: Mixed messages on prostate cancer testing proved deadly for my husband | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Mixed messages on prostate cancer testing prove deadly

items.title: Mixed messages on prostate cancer testing proved deadly for my husband | Letter
items.standfirst: Conflicting advice on whether all men should be tested – and around the test’s reliability – can have heartbreaking consequences, writes Pat SharpeMy husband died of prostate cancer in August, and I read your coverage of the UK National Screening Committee’s recommendations with dread (Expert panel advises against prostate cancer screening for most men in UK, 28 November). I believe the mixed messages being delivered will be deadly for some, as they were for my husband. He delayed having a PSA blood test because he believed it was unreliable and could lead to damaging treatments. He found out too late that he had prostate cancer and that it had spread through his body. He died less than three years after diagnosis aged 68. How did the “harms outweigh the benefits”?Your articles include a wealth of opinion and advice, much of it conflicting. Dr Jayne Spink of Prostate Cancer Research says: “Many men don’t come forward because prostate cancer often has no symptoms in the early stages, and some don’t realise they are at higher risk. This means that we are diagnosing far too many men when their cancer is already advanced and becomes incurable” (What is prostate cancer and should I be worried if I wee a lot at night? 28 November). She is a clear proponent of aiming for early diagnosis. Yet Cancer Research UK “supports” the conclusion that there isn’t enough evidence that screening would do more good than harm, and the chair of the Royal College of GPs is still keen on discussing with patients the “risks and benefits of conducting a PSA [prostate specific antigen] test”. My widow inner-voice asks: what risks and harm outweigh dying unnecessarily? Continue reading...
items.content: Conflicting advice on whether all men should be tested – and around the test’s reliability – can have heartbreaking consequences, writes Pat SharpeMy husband died of prostate cancer in August, and I read your coverage of the UK National Screening Committee’s recommendations with dread (Expert panel advises against prostate cancer screening for most men in UK, 28 November). I believe the mixed messages being delivered will be deadly for some, as they were for my husband. He delayed having a PSA blood test because he believed it was unreliable and could lead to damaging treatments. He found out too late that he had prostate cancer and that it had spread through his body. He died less than three years after diagnosis aged 68. How did the “harms outweigh the benefits”?Your articles include a wealth of opinion and advice, much of it conflicting. Dr Jayne Spink of Prostate Cancer Research says: “Many men don’t come forward because prostate cancer often has no symptoms in the early stages, and some don’t realise they are at higher risk. This means that we are diagnosing far too many men when their cancer is already advanced and becomes incurable” (What is prostate cancer and should I be worried if I wee a lot at night? 28 November). She is a clear proponent of aiming for early diagnosis. Yet Cancer Research UK “supports” the conclusion that there isn’t enough evidence that screening would do more good than harm, and the chair of the Royal College of GPs is still keen on discussing with patients the “risks and benefits of conducting a PSA [prostate specific antigen] test”. My widow inner-voice asks: what risks and harm outweigh dying unnecessarily? Continue reading...

ai_summary: A woman's husband died from prostate cancer after delaying a PSA test.
He believed the test was unreliable and could lead to damaging treatments.
Conflicting advice exists regarding prostate cancer screening for men.
Some doctors advocate for early diagnosis due to lack of early symptoms.
Cancer Research UK supports limited screening due to lack of evidence.

clusters.title: We must warn travellers about the risk of methanol poisoning | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Warn travellers about methanol poisoning risk

items.title: We must warn travellers about the risk of methanol poisoning | Letters
items.standfirst: Jim Dickson MP says much has been done since the death of Simone White, but a wider campaign is needed to educate tourists on the dangers of drinking spirits in countries where methanol-lacing occurs With 14,600 deaths caused by suspected methanol poisoning incidents worldwide since 2015, much more needs to be done to prevent tragedies like the death of Simone White in Laos last year (Brain damage, blindness and death: the global trail of trauma left by methanol-laced alcohol, 29 November).Following campaigning by bereaved families and supportive MPs, the UK government has included education about methanol dangers in the national curriculum and strengthened Foreign Office advice to travellers, extending the warning to more countries. We now need a wider national campaign involving travel companies, with a message that in countries such as Indonesia, which has the highest number of reported incidents of suspected methanol poisoning globally in the past 10 years, spirits should be avoided altogether.Jim Dickson MPLabour, Dartford Continue reading...
items.content: Jim Dickson MP says much has been done since the death of Simone White, but a wider campaign is needed to educate tourists on the dangers of drinking spirits in countries where methanol-lacing occurs With 14,600 deaths caused by suspected methanol poisoning incidents worldwide since 2015, much more needs to be done to prevent tragedies like the death of Simone White in Laos last year (Brain damage, blindness and death: the global trail of trauma left by methanol-laced alcohol, 29 November).Following campaigning by bereaved families and supportive MPs, the UK government has included education about methanol dangers in the national curriculum and strengthened Foreign Office advice to travellers, extending the warning to more countries. We now need a wider national campaign involving travel companies, with a message that in countries such as Indonesia, which has the highest number of reported incidents of suspected methanol poisoning globally in the past 10 years, spirits should be avoided altogether.Jim Dickson MPLabour, Dartford Continue reading...

ai_summary: Since 2015, 14,600 deaths globally have been linked to methanol poisoning.
The UK government added methanol danger education to the national curriculum.
Foreign Office advice to travelers now includes more countries.
A wider campaign involving travel companies is needed.
Spirits should be avoided in countries with high methanol poisoning incidents.

clusters.title: Science journal retracts study on safety of Monsanto’s Roundup: ‘Serious ethical concerns’
clusters.neutral_headline: Science journal retracts study on safety of Monsanto’s Roundup

items.title: Science journal retracts study on safety of Monsanto’s Roundup: ‘Serious ethical concerns’
items.standfirst: Paper published in 2000 found glyphosate was not harmful, while internal emails later revealed company’s influenceThe journal Regulatory Toxicology and Pharmacology has formally retracted a sweeping scientific paper published in 2000 that became a key defense for Monsanto’s claim that Roundup herbicide and its active ingredient glyphosate don’t cause cancer. Martin van den Berg, the journal’s editor in chief, said in a note accompanying the retraction that he had taken the step because of “serious ethical concerns regarding the independence and accountability of the authors of this article and the academic integrity of the carcinogenicity studies presented”.The paper, titled Safety Evaluation and Risk Assessment of the Herbicide Roundup and Its Active Ingredient, Glyphosate, for Humans, concluded that Monsanto’s glyphosate-based weed killers posed no health risks to humans – no cancer risks, no reproductive risks, no adverse effects on development of endocrine systems in people or animals. Continue reading...
items.content: Paper published in 2000 found glyphosate was not harmful, while internal emails later revealed company’s influenceThe journal Regulatory Toxicology and Pharmacology has formally retracted a sweeping scientific paper published in 2000 that became a key defense for Monsanto’s claim that Roundup herbicide and its active ingredient glyphosate don’t cause cancer. Martin van den Berg, the journal’s editor in chief, said in a note accompanying the retraction that he had taken the step because of “serious ethical concerns regarding the independence and accountability of the authors of this article and the academic integrity of the carcinogenicity studies presented”.The paper, titled Safety Evaluation and Risk Assessment of the Herbicide Roundup and Its Active Ingredient, Glyphosate, for Humans, concluded that Monsanto’s glyphosate-based weed killers posed no health risks to humans – no cancer risks, no reproductive risks, no adverse effects on development of endocrine systems in people or animals. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A journal retracted a 2000 paper defending Roundup's safety.
The retraction cited "serious ethical concerns" about the authors.
The paper claimed glyphosate posed no health risks to humans.
The paper stated no cancer, reproductive, or endocrine system effects.
The retraction suggests the study lacked independence and integrity.

clusters.title: Experience: I gave birth to the world’s first IVF boy
clusters.neutral_headline: Experience: I gave birth to the world’s first IVF boy

items.title: Experience: I gave birth to the world’s first IVF boy
items.standfirst: My husband and I were unable to have children, and then we heard about a new experimental techniqueI was 26 when my gynaecologist told me that my fallopian tubes were blocked and there would be no way I could get pregnant. I was devastated. I had always wanted children. It was 1972; I was living in Bishopbriggs, near Glasgow, and working as a college lecturer. IVF didn’t exist, and when my husband and I put our names down to adopt a baby, we were told we had very little chance because few babies were available to adopt at the time. Meanwhile, my gynaecologist tried to open my fallopian tubes. It didn’t work.I refused to accept that I had no options. I read every article I could about fertility treatment. After three years, I heard about a medical breakthrough by gynaecologist Patrick Steptoe and physiologist Robert Edwards. It was described as very experimental and new. Continue reading...
items.content: My husband and I were unable to have children, and then we heard about a new experimental techniqueI was 26 when my gynaecologist told me that my fallopian tubes were blocked and there would be no way I could get pregnant. I was devastated. I had always wanted children. It was 1972; I was living in Bishopbriggs, near Glasgow, and working as a college lecturer. IVF didn’t exist, and when my husband and I put our names down to adopt a baby, we were told we had very little chance because few babies were available to adopt at the time. Meanwhile, my gynaecologist tried to open my fallopian tubes. It didn’t work.I refused to accept that I had no options. I read every article I could about fertility treatment. After three years, I heard about a medical breakthrough by gynaecologist Patrick Steptoe and physiologist Robert Edwards. It was described as very experimental and new. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A woman was told her fallopian tubes were blocked in 1972.
She was unable to conceive naturally and wanted children.
She learned about a new experimental technique for fertility.
The technique was developed by Patrick Steptoe and Robert Edwards.
The woman became pregnant and gave birth to the world's first IVF boy.

clusters.title: Rising racism blamed for collapse in number of foreign nurses coming to UK
clusters.neutral_headline: Rising racism blamed for collapse in number of foreign nurses

items.title: Rising racism blamed for collapse in number of foreign nurses coming to UK
items.standfirst: Number of overseas nurses and midwives registered between April and September was half that of a year agoThe number of overseas nurses and midwives coming to the UK is collapsing, figures reveal, with rising racism and changes to immigration rules blamed for the fall.Between April and September, 6,321 nurses and midwives from abroad joined the register of those licensed to practice in the UK, compared with 12,534 who did so in the same period in 2024. Continue reading...
items.content: Number of overseas nurses and midwives registered between April and September was half that of a year agoThe number of overseas nurses and midwives coming to the UK is collapsing, figures reveal, with rising racism and changes to immigration rules blamed for the fall.Between April and September, 6,321 nurses and midwives from abroad joined the register of those licensed to practice in the UK, compared with 12,534 who did so in the same period in 2024. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The number of overseas nurses coming to the UK is declining.
Rising racism and immigration rule changes are blamed.
Between April and September, 6,321 nurses registered in the UK.
In the same period of 2024, 12,534 nurses registered.
The decline is a significant drop in nurse registration numbers.

clusters.title: GPs failing older people living with frailty, National Audit Office finds
clusters.neutral_headline: GPs failing older people living with frailty

items.title: GPs failing older people living with frailty, National Audit Office finds
items.standfirst: Of patients diagnosed with condition in 2024/25, only 18% were assessed for fall risk and just 16% had a medical reviewGPs are failing to provide adequate support for people living with frailty, an independent watchdog has found.Frailty is a syndrome related to ageing and in which body systems gradually lose their in-built reserves. Symptoms include exhaustion and people living with frailty are more likely to be housebound. Continue reading...
items.content: Of patients diagnosed with condition in 2024/25, only 18% were assessed for fall risk and just 16% had a medical reviewGPs are failing to provide adequate support for people living with frailty, an independent watchdog has found.Frailty is a syndrome related to ageing and in which body systems gradually lose their in-built reserves. Symptoms include exhaustion and people living with frailty are more likely to be housebound. Continue reading...

ai_summary: GPs are failing to provide adequate support for frail patients.
A National Audit Office report found this failure.
Only 18% of patients were assessed for fall risk.
Just 16% had a medical review for frailty.
Frailty is a syndrome related to aging.

clusters.title: Streeting orders review into mental health and ADHD diagnoses

items.title: Streeting orders review into mental health and ADHD diagnoses
items.standfirst: The health secretary says the aim is to tackle a rising demand for services and pressure on the NHS.
items.content: The health secretary says the aim is to tackle a rising demand for services and pressure on the NHS.

items.title: Health Sec Review Into Mental Health and ADHD Diagnoses

The review concerns mental health and ADHD diagnoses.
The aim is to address rising demand for services.

The review is a response to increasing diagnoses.

clusters.title: I realise now that my view on mental health overdiagnosis was divisive. We all need better evidence | Wes Streeting
clusters.neutral_headline: I realise now that my view on mental health overdiagnosis was divisive

items.title: I realise now that my view on mental health overdiagnosis was divisive. We all need better evidence | Wes Streeting
items.standfirst: The surge in mental ill health is hugely distressing. That’s why I’ve commissioned a review to find out what’s driving itEarlier this year, I appeared on the BBC and was asked a question by Laura Kuenssberg that I hadn’t anticipated: did I believe there’s a problem with mental health overdiagnosis?I gave a simple answer, that yes, I did think there was overdiagnosis, that too many people were being written off, and too many people weren’t getting the support they needed.Wes Streeting is the secretary of state for health and social care and Labour MP for Ilford NorthDo you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading...
items.content: The surge in mental ill health is hugely distressing. ai_summary: The author, Wes Streeting, discussed mental health overdiagnosis.
He was asked about overdiagnosis on the BBC.
He stated he believed there was overdiagnosis.
He felt too many people were being written off.
He commissioned a review to find out what is driving it.

clusters.title: Wheelchair worry for young disabled people | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Wheelchair worry for young disabled people

items.title: Wheelchair worry for young disabled people | Letters
items.standfirst: Chris Burgess says her daughter has had to reapply for a wheelchair seven times, in response to an article by Paul Sagar. Plus a letter from Charlie HislopPaul Sagar writes eloquently about his experience of the wheelchair service as a well-educated adult, with some access to funds (‘I wish I could say I kept my cool’: my maddening experience with the NHS wheelchair service, 2 December). My 38-year-old daughter was born with a similar level of spinal injury. A wheelchair that is used all day, every day disintegrates after about five years, so she has had to reapply for one seven times. Imagine trying to attend school while negotiating to obtain this essential equipment.Statistics that support a high level of satisfaction with the wheelchair service do not reflect the experiences of younger disabled people who cannot walk or stand. Disability increases with age, and the typical wheelchair user is an elderly person, often a part-time user who can walk indoors. This may account for the satisfaction with the wheelchair service by older users, who are less dependent on a wheelchair than younger users. Chris BurgessStockport, Greater Manchester Continue reading...

My 38-year-old daughter was born with a similar level of spinal injury. A wheelchair that is used all day, every day disintegrates after about five years, so she has had to reapply for one seven times. Imagine trying to attend school while negotiating to obtain this essential equipment.Statistics that support a high level of satisfaction with the wheelchair service do not reflect the experiences of younger disabled people who cannot walk or stand. Disability increases with age, and the typical wheelchair user is an elderly person, often a part-time user who can walk indoors. This may account for the satisfaction with the wheelchair service by older users, who are less dependent on a wheelchair than younger users. Chris BurgessStockport, Greater Manchester Continue reading...

ai_summary: A letter discusses challenges with wheelchair services.
A daughter has reapplied for a wheelchair seven times.
The author responds to an article by Paul Sagar.
Younger disabled people face difficulties with services.
Satisfaction statistics may not reflect younger users' experiences.

clusters.title: Sir Terence English obituary
clusters.neutral_headline: Sir Terence English obituary: Pioneering cardiac surgeon

items.title: Sir Terence English obituary
items.standfirst: Pioneering cardiac surgeon who directed the Papworth hospital heart transplant programmeIn August 1979 the cardiac surgeon Terence English, who has died aged 93, was poised to carry out a heart transplant at Papworth hospital in Cambridgeshire. If it did not go to plan, the operation, as well as being a tragedy for the patient, would end his vision for a Papworth heart transplant programme. Reminiscing at Papworth 40 years later, he said: “I very much had my back to the wall. I had a shot and I was going to take it.”A heart transplant is the only lifeline for people with end-stage heart failure, and being able to carry out such an operation successfully had long been a goal for cardiac surgeons. Christiaan Barnard in South Africa performed the first human-to-human heart transplant in 1967, and between 1968 and 1969 Donald Ross carried out three in the UK, but the longest a patient had survived was 107 days. It was thought to be a false dawn, and in 1973 the UK chief medical officer put a moratorium on the procedure. Continue reading...
items.content: Pioneering cardiac surgeon who directed the Papworth hospital heart transplant programmeIn August 1979 the cardiac surgeon Terence English, who has died aged 93, was poised to carry out a heart transplant at Papworth hospital in Cambridgeshire. If it did not go to plan, the operation, as well as being a tragedy for the patient, would end his vision for a Papworth heart transplant programme. Reminiscing at Papworth 40 years later, he said: “I very much had my back to the wall. I had a shot and I was going to take it.”A heart transplant is the only lifeline for people with end-stage heart failure, and being able to carry out such an operation successfully had long been a goal for cardiac surgeons. Christiaan Barnard in South Africa performed the first human-to-human heart transplant in 1967, and between 1968 and 1969 Donald Ross carried out three in the UK, but the longest a patient had survived was 107 days. It was thought to be a false dawn, and in 1973 the UK chief medical officer put a moratorium on the procedure. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Sir Terence English, a cardiac surgeon, has died at age 93.
He directed the Papworth hospital heart transplant program.
He was poised to perform a heart transplant in 1979.
He performed the first successful heart transplant in the UK.
He faced challenges in establishing the transplant program.

items.title: NHS must take elderly infections more seriously, Chris Whitty warns
items.standfirst: England's chief medical officer says doctors do not appreciate risk of heart attack and stroke, as flu cases rise.
items.content: England's chief medical officer says doctors do not appreciate risk of heart attack and stroke, as flu cases rise.

ai_summary: England's chief medical officer, Chris Whitty, says doctors do not appreciate the risk of heart attack and stroke.
Whitty's warning comes as flu cases are rising across England, putting pressure on the NHS.
He emphasized the need for better understanding of infection risks in older adults.
The NHS should improve its approach to managing infections in the elderly population.
Whitty highlighted the importance of proactive measures to protect vulnerable individuals.
